commit_message:
Manila share support Recycle Bin

Add support share Recycle Bin, the end user can soft delete
share to Recycle Bin, and can restore the share within 7 dyas,
otherwise the share will be deleted automatically.

Partially-Implements: blueprint manila-share-support-recycle-bin

Change-Id: I9359387267aa617f07e977e30da11efaead2b171

commit_message:
TripleO: Reduce tempest test scope

This change reduces scope of tempest tests in tripleo job, so that we
run only subset of test cases used in TripleO repos.

Change-Id: Idecb41c3cd78e6cc87f324f41ed77b981c3025ce
(cherry picked from commit a73d22babd41a67510cea48747fe95b3330ec1bc)
(cherry picked from commit 5d581f04389cda0ece093fcc599e8e4b1d13cd6e)

commit_message:
Improve support for tags

Previously we had defined some tags but there wasn't any way to make use of them(like galera_server-backups), this change improves tag support

commit_message:
Skip port create if MAC is blank

During redifsh inspect, skip the creation of ports for
any nics that are reported without a MAC address.

Story: #2009016
Task: #42736

subject: Train only - Fix py3 support for bootloader default config load
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2021-06-29 18:15:55.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/ironic-python-agent/commit/43b1426b9681b76cc3ef385e690659fe3115c5a6', 'message': "Train only - Fix py3 support for bootloader default config load

When the support to load the default bootloader configuration was
backported to stable train, I modified it to pass python2 unit tests
as well as ultimately attempt to be compatible.

It might have actually worked! What did not work, was that same file
open format on Python3 in actual production cases where unicode bytes
were being loaded from a file. This is because we couldn't explicitly
declare the utf-16 encoding necessary on the file open, which resulted
in Python3 thinking it was loading a non-uncode file, and promtply
failing when attempting.

Since python2 is past it's End of Support, and any compatability we try
and keep is because we're nice people, I'm retcon'ing the compatability
in https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/ironic-python-agent/+/796031
in preference for python3 functionality, and issuing a nice warning
message saying to upgrade Python.

This issue was identified in RHOSP testing with python 3.6, with
partition images where the deployment would fail with reporting
that the ascii codec could not decode 0xFF which indicates that the
contents are being handled as something other than utf-16, and it
is hitting a constraint in string handling in Python where ascii and
utf-8 character code points are expected to always be <0xFF.

rhbz#1977417

Change-Id: I08664c2b3900448633837e40098a0ff9f0bd65f7

commit_message:
Train only - Fix py3 support for bootloader default config load

When the support to load the default bootloader configuration was
backported to stable train, I modified it to pass python2 unit tests
as well as ultimately attempt to be compatible.

It might have actually worked! What did not work for Python3 when the
UTF-16 codepoint delimiter file was encountered in a production case.
This passed CI originally just fine, however Ubuntu images do not have
the delimiter codepoint, where as RHEL images *do* have a UTF-16
delimiter at the start of the file.

On python3, with the python2 compatible code, the file was being opened
as ascii or UTF-8, which we know as the same rule applies for both. All
code points must be <0xFF. This resulted in the file open itself to fail,
as encoding support differs between Python2 and Python3.

What this patch does now is separately handle the case of if python2,
to use the new preview python3 io subsystem previewed in python2 to
open the file properly, and present the UTF-16 encoded results.

This issue was identified in RHOSP testing with python 3.6, with
partition images where the deployment would fail with reporting
that the ascii codec could not decode 0xFF which indicates that the
contents are being handled as something other than utf-16, and it
is hitting a constraint in string handling in Python where ascii and
utf-8 character code points are expected to always be <0xFF.

Story: 2009020
Task: 42742
rhbz#1977417

Change-Id: I08664c2b3900448633837e40098a0ff9f0bd65f7

commit_message:
setup.cfg: Replace dashes with underscores

Setuptools v54.1.0 introduces a warning that the use of dash-separated
options in 'setup.cfg' will not be supported in a future version [1].
Get ahead of the issue by replacing the dashes with underscores. Without
this, we see 'UserWarning' messages like the following on new enough
versions of setuptools:

  UserWarning: Usage of dash-separated 'description-file' will not be
  supported in future versions. Please use the underscore name
  'description_file' instead

[1] https://github.com/pypa/setuptools/commit/a2e9ae4cb

Change-Id: I430301474e2294eb6f2d71fc521c73d23c6f8a55

commit_message:
Remove content-provider to decrease CI time

Since we only use 1 TripleO standalone job, we dont need
to run the content provided job, but only build containers
in the standalone job.

Removing the content-provider job will decrease significatively
the duration of the zuul runs

Change-Id: Ie13c85f8d80e17077d1a5b591a171248ab0eed28

commit_message:
Use default policies in our tests

Made changes to use default policies in our unit and functional tests
rather than referring it from glance/tests/etc/policy.yaml file. Existing
function 'set_policy_rules' can be used to test custom policy rules in
functional testing.

Improvements needed in followup patch:
1. Property protection related unit tests still reads the special policy
from the policy.yaml file, need to make provision to override it instead.

2. Need to remove 'set_policy' function which actually responsible for
above behavior.

Related to blueprint policy-refactor
Change-Id: I0de9b9f9a7de499574101e3366ced730b0cb5fd1

commit_message:
Update min version of tox to use allowlist

commit_message:
Ensure backward compatibility with SQLAlchemy<1.4

In Ib6e3ed40dc8b075c3cecb967b7417097e3cab60d, a breaking change was
introduced to suppose SQLAlchemy 1.4.x but this PS ensures backward
compatibility with 1.3.x.

Change-Id: I73ef4f99f02abc8b1083860f34a8a8e084ad96fd

commit_message:
Do not test detail of oslo::cors

This change makes unit test cases for ironic::cors and
ironic::inspector::cors, so that these tests do not test behavir of
oslo::cors but how oslo::cors resource type is called by ironic::cors
and ironic::inspector::cors.

Change-Id: I2305f4052dcce40c70ae3a16ff2ee6fcd0bfb8d9

commit_message:
Update TOX_CONSTRAINTS_FILE for stable/wallaby

Update the URL to the upper-constraints file to point to the redirect
rule on releases.openstack.org so that anyone working on this branch
will switch to the correct upper-constraints list automatically when
the requirements repository branches.

Until the requirements repository has as stable/wallaby branch, tests will
continue to use the upper-constraints list on master.

Change-Id: Ic64800c031d61718ce4ea710c42669a081ebf107

commit_message:
Update TOX_CONSTRAINTS_FILE for stable/wallaby

Update the URL to the upper-constraints file to point to the redirect
rule on releases.openstack.org so that anyone working on this branch
will switch to the correct upper-constraints list automatically when
the requirements repository branches.

Until the requirements repository has as stable/wallaby branch, tests will
continue to use the upper-constraints list on master.

Change-Id: I5986087281694580acc3c19feed461b5949f7001

commit_message:
Replace deprecated with_lockmode with with_for_update

The Query.with_lockmode() method is deprecated since version 0.9.0
and will be removed in a future release. [1]
This patch replaces it with Query.with_for_update().

[1] https://docs.sqlalchemy.org/en/13/orm/query.html#sqlalchemy.orm.query.Query.with_lockmode

Closes-Bug: #1933985
Change-Id: I8a318200752181defaf5ca4318d1e52f403f82be

subject: Add import system configuration method
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2021-06-18 11:17:08.000000000', 'files': ['sushy_oem_idrac/resources/manager/constants.py', 'requirements.txt', 'sushy_oem_idrac/resources/manager/mappings.py', 'sushy_oem_idrac/tests/unit/test_manager.py', 'sushy_oem_idrac/resources/manager/manager.py', 'sushy_oem_idrac/asynchronous.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/sushy-oem-idrac/commit/5570b1b7b523dec8bd7142edc7dda20279cd3a62', 'message': 'Add import system configuration method

set_virtual_boot_device is also using the import system configuration
action, but its usage is very specific, with retries and rebooting. To
keep it simple, this adds import_system_configuration, which is
asynchronous and returns a TaskMonitor.

Additionally, this changes the case of the header field names used by
the asynchronous.http_call method to make them work with unit tests.
While the requests package can handle real header field names case-
insensitively, when they are mocked in unit tests, case needs to match.

Change-Id: I3b5e620e7b1939a029bd59b4578c0f52c8789598

commit_message:
Add import system configuration method

set_virtual_boot_device is also using the import system configuration
action, but its usage is very specific, with retries and rebooting. To
keep it simple, this adds import_system_configuration, which is
asynchronous and returns a TaskMonitor.

Additionally, this changes the case of the header field names used by
the asynchronous.http_call method to make them work with unit tests.
While the requests package can handle real header field names case-
insensitively, when they are mocked in unit tests, case needs to match.

Story: 2003594
Task: 41576
Change-Id: I3b5e620e7b1939a029bd59b4578c0f52c8789598
(cherry picked from commit 1020e805d368684080660f10a5ee207d119c2b07)

commit_message:
Add reset iDRAC method

Change-Id: I617297d16080f87e61b7cf0605ee44543b33f2c2
(cherry picked from commit 8f42e419d2486dc71f3bdc0d156036e9c634a135)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/sushy-oem-idrac refs/changes/67/797067/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import subprocessfrom urllib.parse import urlparse _IDRAC_IS_READY_RETRIES = 96 _IDRAC_IS_READY_RETRY_DELAY_SEC = 10 def reset_idrac(self, wait=True, ready_wait_time=60): """Reset the iDRAC and wait for it to become ready. :param wait: Whether to return immediately or wait for iDRAC to become operational. :param ready_wait_time: Amount of time in seconds to wait before starting to check on the iDRAC's status. """ self.idrac_card_service.reset_idrac() if not wait: return host = urlparse(self._conn._url).netloc LOG.debug("iDRAC %(host)s was reset, " "waiting for return to operational state", {'host': host}) self._wait_for_idrac(host, ready_wait_time) self._wait_until_idrac_is_ready(host, self._IDRAC_IS_READY_RETRIES, self._IDRAC_IS_READY_RETRY_DELAY_SEC) def _wait_for_idrac_state(self, host, alive=True, ping_count=3, retries=24): """Wait for iDRAC to become pingable or not pingable. :param host: Hostname or IP of the iDRAC interface. :param alive: True for pingable state and False for not pingable state. :param ping_count: Number of consecutive ping results, per 'alive', for success. :param retries: Number of ping retries. :returns: True on reaching specified host ping state; otherwise, False. """ if alive: ping_type = "pingable" else: ping_type = "not pingable" LOG.debug("Waiting for iDRAC %(host)s to become %(ping_type)s", {'host': host, 'ping_type': ping_type}) response_count = 0 while retries > 0: response = self._ping_host(host) retries -= 1 if response == alive: response_count += 1 LOG.debug("iDRAC %(host)s is %(ping_type)s, " "count=%(response_count)s", {'host': host, 'ping_type': ping_type, 'response_count': response_count}) if response_count == ping_count: LOG.debug("Reached specified %(alive)s count for iDRAC " "%(host)s", {'alive': alive, 'host': host}) return True else: response_count = 0 if alive: LOG.debug("iDRAC %(host)s is still not pingable", {'host': host}) else: LOG.debug("iDRAC %(host)s is still pingable", {'host': host}) time.sleep(10) return False def _wait_for_idrac(self, host, post_pingable_wait_time): """Wait for iDRAC to transition from unpingable to pingable. :param host: Hostname or IP of the iDRAC interface. :param post_pingable_wait_time: Amount of time in seconds to wait after the host becomes pingable. :raises: ExtensionError on failure to perform requested operation. """ state_reached = self._wait_for_idrac_state( host, alive=False, ping_count=2, retries=24) if not state_reached: error_msg = ("Timed out waiting iDRAC %(host)s to become not " "pingable", {'host': host}) LOG.error(error_msg) raise sushy.exceptions.ExtensionError(error=error_msg) LOG.debug("iDRAC %(host)s has become not pingable", {'host': host}) state_reached = self._wait_for_idrac_state(host, alive=True, ping_count=3, retries=24) if not state_reached: error_msg = ("Timed out waiting iDRAC %(host)s to become pingable", {'host': host}) LOG.error(error_msg) raise sushy.exceptions.ExtensionError(error=error_msg) LOG.debug("iDRAC %(host)s has become pingable", {'host': host}) time.sleep(post_pingable_wait_time) def _wait_until_idrac_is_ready(self, host, retries, retry_delay): """Wait until the iDRAC is in a ready state. :param host: Hostname or IP of the iDRAC interface. :param retries: The number of times to check if the iDRAC is ready. :param retry_delay: The number of seconds to wait between retries. :raises: ExtensionError on failure to perform requested operation. """ while retries > 0: LOG.debug("Checking to see if iDRAC %(host)s is ready", {'host': host}) if self.lifecycle_service.is_idrac_ready(): LOG.debug("iDRAC %(host)s is ready", {'host': host}) return LOG.debug("iDRAC %(host)s is not ready", {'host': host}) retries -= 1 if retries > 0: time.sleep(retry_delay) if retries == 0: error_msg = ("Timed out waiting iDRAC %(host)s to become " "ready after reset", {'host': host}) LOG.error(error_msg) raise sushy.exceptions.ExtensionError(error=error_msg) def _ping_host(self, host): """Ping the hostname or IP of a host. :param host: Hostname or IP. :returns: True if host is alive; otherwise, False. """ response = subprocess.call(["ping", "-c", "1", host]) return response == 0

commit_message:
Add resources to put iDRAC in known good state

This change adds the iDRACCardService, JobCollection, JobService, and
LCService resources. Those offer actions to reset the iDRAC, get jobs,
delete jobs, and check if iDRAC is ready.

Change-Id: I29ce49c0865a610f2fb10f5072893bbf51b47303
Story: 2007617
Task: 40985
(cherry picked from commit 910d573c30ac2b090f8b0781233aa59bcfae5fdf)

Update export system configuration

- Add optional parameters export_use and include_in_export to private
export system configuration method.
- Add public export_system_configuration method.

commit_message:
Add export system configuration

This change adds support for exporting system configuration. The
configuration of the entire system or individual subsystems, such as
iDRAC, BIOS, NIC, and RAID, can be exported.

Change-Id: Ia7db0223d72566cf4a4d013a35ef2782f273695f
Co-Authored-By: Sonali Borkar <sonaliborkar85@gmail.com>
(cherry picked from commit b9d65b5ef2f2d41282a096198111014772edb83f)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/sushy-oem-idrac refs/changes/27/796227/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Copyright (c) 2020-2021 Dell Inc. or its subsidiaries. #from sushy_oem_idrac.resources import common as res_common from sushy_oem_idrac.resources.manager import mappings as mgr_maps export_system_configuration = res_common.ExportActionField( lambda key, **kwargs: key.endswith( '#OemManager.ExportSystemConfiguration')) @property def export_system_configuration_uri(self): return self._actions.export_system_configuration.target_uri operation. def get_allowed_export_system_config_values(self): """Get the allowed values of export system configuration. :returns: A set of allowed values. """ export_action = self._actions.export_system_configuration allowed_values = export_action.allowed_values[ 'Target@Redfish.AllowableValues'] return set([mgr_maps.EXPORT_CONFIG_VALUE_MAP[value] for value in set(mgr_maps.EXPORT_CONFIG_VALUE_MAP). intersection(allowed_values)]) def _export_system_configuration(self, target): """Export system configuration. It exports system configuration for specified target like NIC, BIOS, RAID. :param target: Component of the system to export the configuration from. Can be the entire system. Valid values can be gotten from `get_allowed_export_system_config_values`. :returns: a response object containing configuration details for the specified target. :raises: InvalidParameterValueError on invalid target. :raises: ExtensionError on failure to perform requested operation """ valid_allowed_targets = self.get_allowed_export_system_config_values() if target not in valid_allowed_targets: raise sushy.exceptions.InvalidParameterValueError( parameter='target', value=target, valid_values=valid_allowed_targets) target = mgr_maps.EXPORT_CONFIG_VALUE_MAP_REV[target] action_data = { 'ShareParameters': { 'Target': target }, 'ExportFormat': "JSON" } try: response = asynchronous.http_call( self._conn, 'post', self.export_system_configuration_uri, data=action_data) LOG.info("Successfully exported system configuration " "for %(target)s", {'target': target}) return response except (sushy.exceptions.ExtensionError, sushy.exceptions.InvalidParameterValueError) as exc: LOG.error('Dell OEM export system configuration failed : %s', exc) raise

commit_message:
Add volume_size_extend opt for volume tests

Volume tests had hardcoded value (1) in case they were creating
a second volume with a different size than the first one
(CONF.volume.volume_size). This is a problem for systems which
have a chunk size other than 1. The patch is adding a new opt
CONF.volume.volume_size_extend which allows customization of an
extended volume size.

Closes-Bug: 1917299
Change-Id: Ic8ae486224cd2a470f4f9bbad62d4d6715cc63ac
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tempest refs/changes/66/797966/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: --- features: - | A new config for volume tests is added which allows to specify chunk size which is beneficial for tested systems where the chunk size is other than 1 (originally hardoced in the tests).: CONF.volume.chunk_size

commit_message:
Add Devstack Installation Guide

This commit added a guide to test out oslo.metrics using Devstack.

Change-Id: I2e9c8eb5da687684df3dcd897ce1f90a18a11dbf
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/oslo.metrics refs/changes/47/796147/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: Testing with DevStack ##################### This section describes how to test out oslo.metrics and collect oslo.messaging metric data using Devstack. Download DevStack ----------------- .. code-block:: console $ git clone https://opendev.org/openstack/devstack $ cd devstack The ``devstack`` repo contains a script that installs OpenStack and templates for configuration files. Create a local.conf ------------------- Create a ``local.conf`` file with four passwords preset at the root of the devstack git repo. .. code-block:: ini [[local|localrc]] ADMIN_PASSWORD=secret DATABASE_PASSWORD=$ADMIN_PASSWORD RABBIT_PASSWORD=$ADMIN_PASSWORD SERVICE_PASSWORD=$ADMIN_PASSWORD LIBS_FROM_GIT=oslo.messaging [[post-config|$NOVA_CONF]] [oslo_messaging_metrics] metrics_enabled = True This is the minimum required config to get started with Devstack including oslo.metrics. Start the install ----------------- .. code-block:: console $ ./stack.sh This will take a 15 - 20 minutes, largely depending on the speed of your internet connection. Many git trees and packages will be installed during this process. Start the Metrics Server ------------------------ .. code-block:: console $ oslo-metrics This command will start oslo.metrics server and start collecting oslo.messaging metrics sending from OpenStack services. oslo.metrics exporter will serve on port 3000 by default. Example Output -------------- An example of oslo.metrics collecting metrics from Nova: .. code-block:: console ubuntu@devstack:~/devstack$ oslo-metrics 2021-06-12 14:32:26.091 466289 INFO oslo.metrics.__main__ [-] Start oslo.metrics 2021-06-12 14:57:50.632 466289 DEBUG oslo.metrics.__main__ [-] wait for socket.recv serve /usr/local/lib/python3.8/dist-packages/oslo_metrics/__main__.py:73 2021-06-12 14:57:50.632 466289 DEBUG oslo.metrics.__main__ [-] got message serve /usr/local/lib/python3.8/dist-packages/oslo_metrics/__main__.py:76 2021-06-12 14:57:50.633 466289 INFO oslo.metrics.message_router [-] Get labels with rpc_client_processing_seconds: {'call_type': 'call', 'exchange': None, 'topic': 'conductor', 'namespace': 'baseapi', 'version': '1.0', 'server': None, 'fanout': None, 'method': 'ping', 'timeout': None, 'process': ''} 2021-06-12 14:57:50.633 466289 INFO oslo.metrics.message_router [-] Perform action observe for rpc_client_processing_seconds metrics 2021-06-12 14:57:50.633 466289 DEBUG oslo.metrics.__main__ [-] wait for socket.recv serve /usr/local/lib/python3.8/dist-packages/oslo_metrics/__main__.py:73 2021-06-12 14:57:50.633 466289 DEBUG oslo.metrics.__main__ [-] got message serve /usr/local/lib/python3.8/dist-packages/oslo_metrics/__main__.py:76 2021-06-12 14:57:50.633 466289 INFO oslo.metrics.message_router [-] Get labels with rpc_client_invocation_end_total: {'call_type': 'call', 'exchange': None, 'topic': 'conductor', 'namespace': 'baseapi', 'version': '1.0', 'server': None, 'fanout': None, 'method': 'ping', 'timeout': None, 'process': ''} 2021-06-12 14:57:50.633 466289 INFO oslo.metrics.message_router [-] Perform action inc for rpc_client_invocation_end_total metrics` Gathering Metrics ----------------- To gather metrics from oslo.metrics, configure Prometheus to scrape from port 3000 where oslo.metrics is running.

commit_message:
Release Openstack-Ansible

The trailing deadline is on 02 July, 2021. Here we propose a final RC
but I think that we need a final release after this one.

https://releases.openstack.org/xena/schedule.html#wallaby-cycle-trailing-release-deadline

Change-Id: Ic2079f19e670cfaf11d496a65f950796f915f9c6

commit_message:
Change scale-down example with compute instead of controller

Since scaling down controllers was never supported, it might be a better
to use computes as example to prevent people from scaling down
controllers.

Change-Id: Id1508dbfa46292581bd20e15e79370b584183322

commit_message:
Release oslo's independent deliverables

First release of etcd3gw under the openstack umbrella, support of
python 2 has been dropped so this is why I released a major version.
However I don't know how far we could consider etcd3gw as stable.

Proposing a new minor version of oslo.reports, oslo.log, and
oslo.rootwrap as py2 stuffs (conditions, six, etc...) have been cleaned.

Change-Id: Ie08cda2ed6285c9ce506432cb516161a85b49076

commit_message:
Unskip test_allocate_ips_are_from_correct_subnet test

This test was skipped due to bug in Neutron with [1] and [2].

Now it is properly skipped by neutron-tempest-plugin when required API
extension isn't available [3]. It should also be running fine when [2]
will be merged.

[1] https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/openstack-tempest-skiplist/+/797320
[2] https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/openstack-tempest-skiplist/+/798068
[3] https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/neutron-tempest-plugin/+/797594
[4] https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/neutron/+/797595

Closes-Bug: #1933115

Change-Id: I54ee3fcf48f20703d0c43a200354002c693e6bd9

commit_message:
Use py3 as the default runtime for tox

Moving on py3 as the default runtime for tox to avoid to update this at
each new cycle.

Wallaby support officially the following runtimes [1]:
- Python 3.6
- Python 3.8

During Victoria Python 3.7 was used as the default runtime [2] however this
version isn't longer officially supported.

[1] https://governance.openstack.org/tc/reference/runtimes/wallaby.html#python-runtimes-for-wallaby
[2] https://governance.openstack.org/tc/reference/runtimes/victoria.html#python-runtimes-for-victoria

Change-Id: Id4b5cb679c60fda4132a10f684ed5128c0965230

subject: relinker: don't bother checking for previous tombstone links
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2021-06-30 15:10:08.000000000', 'files': ['test/unit/cli/test_relinker.py', 'swift/cli/relinker.py', 'etc/object-server.conf-sample'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/swift/commit/f7fbc48b587237f795982bfd338d8e2c25002a22', 'message': "relinker: don't bother checking for previous tombstone links

Since [1] the relinker had special case handling for EEXIST errors
caused by a different inode tombstone already existing in the next
partition power location: the relinker would check to see if the
existing next part power tombstone linked to a tombstone in a previous
part power (i.e. < current part power) location, and if so tolerate
the EEXIST.

This special case handling is no longer necessary because the relinker
will now tolerate an EEXIST when linking a tombstone provided the two
files have the same timestamp. There is therefore no need to search
previous part power locations for a tombstone that does link with the
next part power location.

The link_check_limit is no longer used but the --link-check-limit
command line option is still allowed (although ignored) for backwards
compatibility.

[1] Related-Change-Id: If9beb9efabdad64e81d92708f862146d5fafb16c

Change-Id: Iae4ae0f0e3cf9a5de4219643b12af785b69bce20
"}]
commit_message:
relinker: don't bother checking for previous tombstone links

Since [1] the relinker had special case handling for EEXIST errors
caused by a different inode tombstone already existing in the next
partition power location: the relinker would check to see if the
existing next part power tombstone linked to a tombstone in a previous
part power (i.e. < current part power) location, and if so tolerate
the EEXIST.

This special case handling is no longer necessary because the relinker
will now tolerate an EEXIST when linking a tombstone provided the two
files have the same timestamp. There is therefore no need to search
previous part power locations for a tombstone that does link with the
next part power location.

The link_check_limit is no longer used but the --link-check-limit
command line option is still allowed (although ignored) for backwards
compatibility.

[1] Related-Change-Id: If9beb9efabdad64e81d92708f862146d5fafb16c

Change-Id: Iae4ae0f0e3cf9a5de4219643b12af785b69bce20
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/swift refs/changes/14/798914/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
deleted_lines: # Maximum number of partition power locations to check for a valid link target # if the relinker encounters an existing tombstone, but with different inode, # in the next partition power location. If the relinker fails to make a link # because a different tombstone already exists in the next partition power # location then it will try to validate that the existing tombstone links to a # valid target in the current partition power location, or previous partition # power locations, in descending order. This option limits the number of # partition power locations searched, including the current partition power, # and should be a whole number. A value of 0 implies that no validation is # attempted, and an error is logged, when an existing tombstone prevents link # creation. A value of 1 implies that an existing link is accepted if it links # to a tombstone in the current partition power location. The default value of # 2 implies that an existing link is acceptable if it links to a tombstone in # the current or previous partition power locations. Increased values may be # useful if previous partition power increases have failed to cleanup # tombstones from their old locations, causing duplicate tombstones with # different inodes to be relinked to the next partition power location. # link_check_limit = 2 #

commit_message:
Drop warnings enable filter

[1] Enabled warnings without specifying category,
leading to all sort of warnings enabled, this patch
drops it and let it to consumers to enable warnings
types which they are interested in.

[1] https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/oslo.utils/+/790429

Closes-Bug: #1934098
Change-Id: I822138c18e0932e8f7e3dc62267f167876c962ae

commit_message:
baremetal: Don't start Docker after install on Debian/Ubuntu

docker-ce on Debian/Ubuntu gets started just after installation, before
baremetal role configures daemon.json - which results in iptables rules
being implemented - but not removed on docker engine restart.

Closes-Bug: #1923203

Change-Id: Ib1faa092e0b8f0668d1752490a34d0c2165d58d2
(cherry picked from commit bc96179195de171a693b83405a472dddda596bff)

commit_message:
Update TOX_CONSTRAINTS_FILE for stable/wallaby

Update the URL to the upper-constraints file to point to the redirect
rule on releases.openstack.org so that anyone working on this branch
will switch to the correct upper-constraints list automatically when
the requirements repository branches.

Until the requirements repository has as stable/wallaby branch, tests will
continue to use the upper-constraints list on master.

Change-Id: Ie798cb4868eeb58c70a95cd9c53926c9ba270ffe

subject: Replace deprecated with_lockmode with with_for_update
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2021-07-01 06:41:10.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/watcher/commit/51c15cad645f087a472e238e529379d4b296ce27', 'message': 'Replace deprecated with_lockmode with with_for_update

The Query.with_lockmode() method is deprecated since version 0.9.0
and will be removed in a future release. [1]
This patch replaces it with Query.with_for_update().
The 'faultstring' was been modified to 'Exactly 5 or 6 columns has to be
specified for iterator expression', so adds one space between "iterator"
and "expression" for 'expected_error_msg'.

Also use upper-constraints in doc build to avoid issues in pdf build.

[1]
https://docs.sqlalchemy.org/en/13/orm/query.html#sqlalchemy.orm.query.Query.with_lockmode

commit_message:
Replace deprecated with_lockmode with with_for_update

The Query.with_lockmode() method is deprecated since version 0.9.0
and will be removed in a future release. [1]
This patch replaces it with Query.with_for_update().
The 'faultstring' was been modified to 'Exactly 5 or 6 columns has to be
specified for iterator expression', so adds one space between "iterator"
and "expression" for 'expected_error_msg'.

Also use upper-constraints in doc build to avoid issues in pdf build.

[1]
https://docs.sqlalchemy.org/en/13/orm/query.html#sqlalchemy.orm.query.Query.with_lockmode

Closes-Bug: #1933226
Change-Id: I0ad514da647bb08790259fd27e56a41f6dbbbaa0
(cherry picked from commit 9ca44fa3ab16ba99c65b75c7fa2fde3b2c160b1d)

commit_message:
magnum: Add CA certificate configuration for internal TLS

Magnum has various sections in its configuration file for OpenStack
clients. When internal TLS is enabled, these may need a CA certificate
to be specified.

This change adds a CA certificate configuration, based on
openstack_cacert, for all clients using internal endpoints.

Note: we are explicitly not adding the configuration for the
[magnum_client] ca_file and [drivers] openstack_ca_file options, since
these use the public endpoint by default. These options may be
provided via custom configuration if necessary.

Change-Id: Ie59b3777c0a2c142b580addd67e279bc4b2f2c90
Co-Authored-By: Kyle Dean
Closes-Bug: #1919389

commit_message:
Avoid unhandled exceptions during connecting to iSCSI portals

Currently we don't properly catch some possible exceptions during
connectiing to iSCSI portals, like failures in "iscsiadm -m session".
Because of this _connect_vol threads can abort unexpectedly in some
failure patterns, and this abort causes hung in subsequent steps
waiting for results from _connct_vol threads.

This change ensures that any exceptions during connecting to iSCSI
portals are handled in the _connect_vol method corectly, to avoid
unexpected abort without updating thread results.

Conflicts:
        os_brick/tests/initiator/connectors/test_iscsi.py

Closes-Bug: #1915678
Change-Id: I0278c502806b99f8ec65cb146e3852e43031e9b8
(cherry picked from commit 4478433550ddab970f106636a4ba5fbba82c5e39)
(cherry picked from commit 57c8f4334c0e58b151f449f3316bb9e1c8ed6da4)
(cherry picked from commit c336cb76b318f987d43ff908a5b7c9d40b5c4dd6)

commit_message:
Fix broken testcase 'test_create_continuous_audit_with_wrong_interval'

The 'faultstring' was been modified to 'Exactly 5 or 6 columns has to be
specified for iterator expression', so adds one space between "iterator"
and "expression" for 'expected_error_msg'.

Closes-Bug: #1933708
Change-Id: I23893376a295d7919ff78a390e06e9b7422098c8

commit_message:
setup.cfg: Replace dashes with underscores

Setuptools v54.1.0 introduces a warning that the use of dash-separated
options in 'setup.cfg' will not be supported in a future version [1].
Get ahead of the issue by replacing the dashes with underscores. Without
this, we see 'UserWarning' messages like the following on new enough
versions of setuptools:

  UserWarning: Usage of dash-separated 'description-file' will not be
  supported in future versions. Please use the underscore name
  'description_file' instead

[1] https://github.com/pypa/setuptools/commit/a2e9ae4cb

Change-Id: Ide4d650a78829a6bc16d86b620e6b3fbed0bba06
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/watcher refs/changes/74/788174/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

If guestarch in PPC/PPC64/PPCLE/PPC64LE/S390/S390X/AARCH64
and virt_type in qemu/kvm, the bus of cdrom is scsi. In some scsi instances,
cdrom_device occupied the unit after disk, If attach a new disk to the

Change-Id: I86e78781e64084e569759642f782ff24f120c7d5
'}]
commit_message:
Returns the max disk/cdrom unit used by scsi controller

If guestarch in PPC/PPC64/PPCLE/PPC64LE/S390/S390X/AARCH64
and virt_type in qemu/kvm, the bus of cdrom is scsi. In some scsi instances,
cdrom_device occupied the unit after disk, If attach a new disk to the
instance, raise libvirtError: id duplicate. This patch fix it, returns the max
disk/cdrom unit used by scsi controller

Change-Id: I86e78781e64084e569759642f782ff24f120c7d5
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/45/683845/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # NOTE(wangyue):Returns the max disk/cdrom unit used by scsi controller addrs_disk = "./devices/disk[@device='disk']/address[@type='drive']" addrs_cdrom = "./devices/disk[@device='cdrom']" for obj in tree.findall(addrs_disk): for obj in tree.findall(addrs_cdrom): if obj.findall("./target[@bus='scsi']"): addrs_cdrom = obj.findall("./address[@type='drive']") ret.append(int(addrs_cdrom[0].get('unit', 0)))
deleted_lines: """Returns the max disk unit used by scsi controller""" addrs = "./devices/disk[@device='disk']/address[@type='drive']" for obj in tree.findall(addrs):

commit_message:
setup.cfg: Replace dashes with underscores

Setuptools v54.1.0 introduces a warning that the use of dash-separated
options in 'setup.cfg' will not be supported in a future version [1].
Get ahead of the issue by replacing the dashes with underscores. Without
this, we see 'UserWarning' messages like the following on new enough
versions of setuptools:

  UserWarning: Usage of dash-separated 'description-file' will not be
  supported in future versions. Please use the underscore name
  'description_file' instead

[1] https://github.com/pypa/setuptools/commit/a2e9ae4cb

Change-Id: I0573f72eb92ddda5392dbf78260a18b17a8d75af

commit_message:
Dropping lower constraints testing

We facing errors related to the new pip resolver, this
topic was discussed on the ML and QA team proposed to
to test lower-constraints [1].

I propose to drop this test because the complexity and recurring pain needed
to maintain that now exceeds the benefits provided by this mechanismes.

[1] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2020-December/019390.html

Change-Id: I9308030b0a16f9a7e085b3e64230cd92dda6ad83
(cherry picked from commit 427afe1f75665592c53b8597d46b9e25078627fa)

commit_message:
Test bundles for focal-wallaby and hirsute-wallaby

These are the test bundles (and any associated changes) for
focal-wallaby and hirsute-wallaby support.

hisute-wallaby test is disabled (moved to dev) due to [1] as bundle may
reference a reactive charm.

[1] https://github.com/juju-solutions/layer-basic/issues/194

Sync charm-helpers

Also pin prometheus2 charm in bundles to focal series as it does not
support groovy or hirsute.

Change-Id: I75602720f8e30be647aa8a1227d565c692ff8170
Co-authored-by: Aurelien Lourot <aurelien.lourot@canonical.com>

revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2021-06-30 20:09:48.000000000', 'files': ['blacklist.txt', 'upper-constraints.txt'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/requirements/commit/23ae3d1cc3f8227bdcae61b33745faa9f1c32df1', 'message': 'Revert "Add neutron to stable upper-constraints"

This reverts commit 1c51379ed4dd3bbe97601c4b8eae9d058b134cb0.

Reason for revert: Neutron is being used also by other projects (like deployment ones) that need to comply with u-c and at the same time need to install specific service versions (with SHAs).
New pip resolver does not allow to have specific SHAs in constraints and thus it needs to be put into requirements, which results in conflict and being unable to install neutron and use u-c at the same time.

Change-Id: I16b30dcce2db84351460cc2c362a42a0b8532b79
'}]
commit_message:
Revert "Add neutron to stable upper-constraints"

This reverts commit 1c51379ed4dd3bbe97601c4b8eae9d058b134cb0.

Reason for revert: Neutron is being used also by other projects (like deployment ones) that need to comply with u-c and at the same time need to install specific service versions (with SHAs).
New pip resolver does not allow to have specific SHAs in constraints and thus it needs to be put into requirements, which results in conflict and being unable to install neutron and use u-c at the same time.

Change-Id: I16b30dcce2db84351460cc2c362a42a0b8532b79

revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2021-06-09 17:47:41.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/b9fc8ed878c9756aa6eafb8058b68b07bacc4001', 'message': "Use TCP keepalives for ovsdb connections

When failing over OVN DB servers from one server to another, the
server which originally hosted the VIP doesn't notice the connection
is gone and doesn't reconnect. Ultimately, this is something that
needs to be fixed in python-ovs, but setting the SO_KEEPALIVE socket
option avoids the issue. This also has the benefit that the client
doesn't need to send 'echo' requests, which can time out on an
overloaded ovsdb-server, which causes a disconnection which then
adds even more load on the ovsdb-server as it has to send the entire
db contents over the wire after the connection.

Closes-Bug: #1930926

commit_message:
Use TCP keepalives for ovsdb connections

When failing over OVN DB servers from one server to another, the
server which originally hosted the VIP doesn't notice the connection
is gone and doesn't reconnect. Ultimately, this is something that
needs to be fixed in python-ovs, but setting the SO_KEEPALIVE socket
option avoids the issue. This also has the benefit that the client
doesn't need to send 'echo' requests, which can time out on an
overloaded ovsdb-server, which causes a disconnection which then
adds even more load on the ovsdb-server as it has to send the entire
db contents over the wire after the connection.

Conflicts: neutron/plugins/ml2/drivers/ovn/mech_driver/ovsdb/impl_idl_ovn.py

Closes-Bug: #1930926
Change-Id: Ie0205785cab307c132fbe409588739685cade7c0
(cherry picked from commit 65cce351d74a9a637fdb2a9d5e0e63445dda9ea9)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/14/795614/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import functools import socketfrom ovs import socket_util from ovs import streamdef add_keepalives(fn): @functools.wraps(fn) def _open(*args, **kwargs): error, sock = fn(*args, **kwargs) try: sock.setsockopt(socket.SOL_SOCKET, socket.SO_KEEPALIVE, 1) except socket.error as e: sock.close() return socket_util.get_exception_errno(e), None return error, sock return _open class NoProbesMixin: @staticmethod def needs_probes(): # If we are using keepalives, we can force probe_interval=0 return False class TCPStream(stream.TCPStream, NoProbesMixin): @classmethod @add_keepalives def _open(cls, suffix, dscp): return super()._open(suffix, dscp) class SSLStream(stream.SSLStream, NoProbesMixin): @classmethod @add_keepalives def _open(cls, suffix, dscp): return super()._open(suffix, dscp) # Overwriting globals in a library is clearly a good idea stream.Stream.register_method("tcp", TCPStream) stream.Stream.register_method("ssl", SSLStream)

commit_message:
Revert "Skip the cases effected by sqlalchemy version update"

This reverts commit 210b12f887ec44e2af91efdba0b94dd7f879cb6a.

Reason for revert: cyborg code bug has fixed, https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/cyborg/+/796676

Change-Id: Ifbd85d8fc8754de4a11a0d2707c991bc5e39cc85

commit_message:
Add build for ansible collections in build-test

Add building for 3 other ansible collections we use in TripleO:
  - ansible-collections/community.general
  - ansible-collections/ansible.posix
  - ansible-collections/ansible.netcommon

Change-Id: I6fe6a11d2121228aef480f4bd564fca422978566

By default, Ansible injects a variable for every fact, prefixed with

configuration option [0] that can be set to False to prevent this

commit_message:
Use ansible_facts to reference facts

By default, Ansible injects a variable for every fact, prefixed with
ansible_. This can result in a large number of variables for each host,
which at scale can incur a performance penalty. Ansible provides a
configuration option [0] that can be set to False to prevent this
injection of facts. In this case, facts should be referenced via
ansible_facts.<fact>.

This change updates all references to Ansible facts within Kolla Ansible
from using individual fact variables to using the items in the
ansible_facts dictionary. This allows users to disable fact variable
injection in their Ansible configuration, which may provide some
performance improvement.

This change disables fact variable injection in the ansible
configuration used in CI, to catch any attempts to use the injected
variables.

[0] https://docs.ansible.com/ansible/latest/reference_appendices/config.html#inject-facts-as-vars

Change-Id: I7e9d5c9b8b9164d4aee3abb4e37c8f28d98ff5d1
Partially-Implements: blueprint performance-improvements

commit_message:
Add support for the keystone_authtoken/service_type parameter

commit_message:
Open cinderlib for xena development

cinderlib is a 'trailing' deliverable type.  The stable/wallaby
branch has just been cut, so transition master to xena development.

Depends-on: https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/releases/+/797422
Change-Id: Ic6be0596fcc4cef40301702c3bac3085468c8daa

commit_message:
Add image_count_total quota enforcement

This makes us enforce a quota on the total number of (non-deleted)
images owned by a user.

Partially-implements: blueprint glance-unified-quotas

Change-Id: I8af124d9307263cd8289d0701fb9a745d13b1d56

commit_message:
Add user_get_image_count() to DB API

This adds an efficient query method for getting a count of a user's
non-deleted images. It can be used by subsequent patches to enforce
the image count quota.

Partially-implements: blueprint glance-unified-quotas

Change-Id: I4d6e071b8d48862032f36c80ee19632a3fe85009
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/glance refs/changes/26/788326/10 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def test_get_image_count(self): for owner, ctxt in self.contexts.items(): count = self.db_api.user_get_image_count(ctxt, ctxt.owner) # Each user has two active images, two staged images, and two # queued images self.assertEqual(6, count)

commit_message:
Add image_stage_total quota enforcement

This makes us enforce a quota on the amount of data a user has in
staging.

Partially-implements: blueprint glance-unified-quotas

Change-Id: I3cca4e589adc0aec138e5933c311aefd69ccee51
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/glance refs/changes/77/788077/18 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: QUOTA_IMAGE_STAGING_TOTAL = 'image_stage_total' def enforce_image_staging_total(context, project_id): _enforce_one(context, project_id, QUOTA_IMAGE_STAGING_TOTAL, lambda: db.user_get_staging_usage(context, project_id))

commit_message:
Add user_get_staging_usage() to DB API

This adds a method that counts the sizes of images that are in the
process of doing an import, indicating that they are using staging
storage resources. We gather images that are in obvious states of
being created via import, as well as any images that appear to be
active but in the middle of a copy, since those could be using staging
resources as well.

This is somewhat mirrored from user_get_storage_usage(). Since there
was no test for that method, this adds a test case for both that and
the new method.

Partially-implements: blueprint glance-unified-quotas

Change-Id: Ic2b045549ac0d6112b0c565d2e993576a5626799
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/glance refs/changes/76/788076/5 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from oslo_utils.fixture import uuidsentinel as uuidsfrom glance import context as glance_context class TestImageStorageUsage(base.TestDriver, base.FunctionalInitWrapper): def setUp(self): db_tests.load(get_db, reset_db) super(TestImageStorageUsage, self).setUp() self.addCleanup(db_tests.reset) self.contexts = {} for owner in (uuids.owner1, uuids.owner2): ctxt = glance_context.RequestContext(project_id=owner) self.contexts[owner] = ctxt statuses = ['queued', 'active', 'uploading', 'deleted'] for status in statuses: for num in range(0, 2): # Make the size of each image differ by status # so we can make sure we count the right one size = statuses.index(status) * 100 image = self.db_api.image_create( ctxt, {'status': status, 'owner': owner, 'size': size, 'name': 'test-%s-%i' % (status, num)}) if status == 'active': # Active images get one location, active if they # are the first. loc_status = num == 0 and 'active' or 'deleted' self.db_api.image_location_add( ctxt, image['id'], {'url': 'foo://bar', 'metadata': {}, 'status': loc_status}) def test_get_staging_usage(self): for owner, ctxt in self.contexts.items(): usage = self.db_api.user_get_staging_usage(ctxt, ctxt.owner) # Each user has two staged images of size 200 each self.assertEqual(400, usage) def test_get_storage_usage(self): for owner, ctxt in self.contexts.items(): usage = self.db_api.user_get_storage_usage(ctxt, ctxt.owner) # Each user has two active images of size 100 each, but only one # has an active location self.assertEqual(100, usage)

subject: Adds a clear error message to operator-set limits
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2021-03-24 20:48:10.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/manila/commit/87c02e6fe33b2c04ad787b9bb2999fb718b6fac0', 'message': 'Adds explicit error message

When a user sets a quota that is greater than 2147483647, an
exlicit error message that "Quota limit should not exceed 2147483647"
is communicated. This is better with regard to the initial message
which was "ERROR: The server has either erred or is
incapable of performing the requested operation. (HTTP 500)."

Closes-Bug: #1908352
Change-Id: I0d301c5f527c3e16e14021b679c85bd51833a1d6

commit_message:
Adds a clear error message to operator-set limits

When an operator sets a limit that is greater than 2147483647, an
explicit error message "Quota limit should not exceed 2147483647"
is communicated. This is better than the initial error message
which was "ERROR: The server has either erred or is
incapable of performing the requested operation. (HTTP 500)."

Closes-Bug: #1908352
Change-Id: I0d301c5f527c3e16e14021b679c85bd51833a1d6
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/manila refs/changes/56/782856/6 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: --- fixes: - | When a quota value greater than 2147483647 is set, the error message "ERROR: Invalid input received:Quota limit should not exceed 2147483647. (HTTP 400)" is communicated to the user.

commit_message:
Alert server for Prometheus with K8s cluster VNF

In this spec, Prometheus will be supported as the metrics server.
Tacker installs required packages in Master/Worker nodes for
Prometheus and sends the configuration files describing alert rules
to Prometheus when instantiating Kubernetes cluster VNF.
Tacker receives alert messages from Prometheus server and invokes
Scale-out/in operations.

Change-Id: Ic7d8dfa49754e72fe08e57a361e7cc8fa09c7d00
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tacker-specs refs/changes/73/786573/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: ============================================================== Alert server for Prometheus with Kubernetes cluster VNF sample ============================================================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/tacker/+spec/prometheus-monitoring Problem description =================== Deploying Kubernetes cluster as VNF instance, it is possible to Scale-out/in its Worker nodes with VNF Lifecycle Management interface defined in ETSI NFV-SOL003 v2.6.1 [#SOL003]_ as described in spec [#Support_scaling_Kubernetes_Worker-nodes_with_Mgmtdriver]_. Managed Kubernetes clusters in public cloud support auto-scaling of Worker nodes when the resource usage in worker nodes exceeds thresholds or when Master nodes cannot assign enough resources to new Pods. To achieve this with Tacker, metrics server to monitor the resource usage of Worker nodes and the number of Pods is required. In this spec, Prometheus is supported as the metrics server. Tacker installs required packages in Master/Worker nodes for Prometheus and sends the configuration files describing alert rules to Prometheus when instantiating Kubernetes cluster VNF. Tacker receives alert messages from Prometheus server and invokes Scale-out/in operations. .. note:: Prometheus server can be part of Kubernetes cluster VNF or can be external service deployed out of VNF. The former case only requires additional procedure to later case, and the specific process for the former case is marked as "optional". Proposed change =============== The following changes are needed: #. New Restful API in Tacker server receiving alert for auto-scaling trigger + Expose alert receiving server + Call Scale-out/in operation on alert message #. New logic in MgmtDriver to configure Prometheus + instantiate_end: + (Optional) deploy Prometheus + Set up Prometheus + Send monitor/alert rule files to Prometheus + terminate_end: + Delete monitor/alert rules in Prometheus + scale_start, scale_end: + Set up Prometheus in new Worker nodes + Add/Remove new monitoring target of Worker nodes Tacker Alert Server -------------------- The alert server exposes IF to receive HTTP requests from metric server. The request may not follow the specifications defined in ESTI NFV because major OSS applications have their own rules to send alert messages. This spec proposes simple and flexible IF for metric servers to ask Tacker to execute auto-heal or auto-scale operations. They can invoke existing Heal or Scale operations with ETSI NFV-SOL003 VNF Lifecycle Management interface, or any original operations to manage their complex applications. To launch an alert server, it should be enabled in ``tacker.conf`` because this is an optional server and should not be launched without metrics server. .. code-block:: [tacker] prometheus_plugin = true The detail of Restful API is described in :ref:`REST API impact`. Instantiate Kubernetes cluster VNF ---------------------------------- This section describes how to instantiate a Kubernetes cluster with Prometheus server for auto-scaling. Instantiating Kubernetes cluster as a VNF instance, MgmtDriver is responsible for installation and configuration of Kubernetes related packages. To support auto-scaling with Prometheus, MgmtDriver may also need to deploy Prometheus server in the VNF or it may be available as pre-built service. The configuration files are generated in ``instantiate_end`` method with runtime information such as IP address of Master/Worker nodes. Design of operation ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ Following depicts the diagram of instantiate process of Kubernetes cluster: :: +---------+ +---------+ | Cluster | | | | Install | | VNFD | | Script | | | +-------+-+ +-+-------+ | | v v +--+-----+-+ +------------------+ | | | Instantiation | | CSAR | | Request with | | | | AdditionalParams | +----------+ +------------------+ | | 5. Update Receiver +-----------------------------------------+ | v v VNFM | +----------------+ | +----+----------+----+ | | | | | TackerServer | | | Alertmanager |<-+ | +-------+------------+ | | | | | | | +----------------+ | | v | | | +-----------------------------------+ | | | | Tacker Conductor | | | | | | | +----------------+ | 3. Generate | | +------------+ +------------+ | | | | | Config | | | Mgmt | | OpenStack | | | | Prometheus | | Files | | | Driver | | Infra | | | | Server |<-+--------------------+ | | Driver | | | | | | | | | | | | | +----------------+ | | +---------+--+ +-----+------+ | | 4. Update | | | | | | Metrics Endpoint | +-----------------------------------+ | and Alert rule | | | | +-----------------------------------------+ 2. Install | | 1. Create VMs Kubernetes cluster +------------+ | +-----------------------------------------+ | | KubernetesCluster VNF | | +--------+---------------+ | | | | | | v v | | +-------------+ +-------------+ | | | +--------+ | | +--------+ | | | | | Worker | | | | Master | | | | | +--------+ | | +--------+ | | | | VM | | VM | | | +-------------+ +-------------+ | +-----------------------------------------+ +-----------------------------------------+ | Hardware Resources | +-----------------------------------------+ #. OpenStackInfraDriver creates new VMs. #. MgmtDriver installs the Kubernetes cluster by ``instantiate_end`` method. #. Execute a shell script in Master/Worker nodes to install Kubernetes. #. Execute a shell script to deploy components for Prometheus as Kubernetes resources. + (Optional) Prometheus server: StatefulSet + (Optional) Alertmanager: StatefulSet + metrics-server: Deployments + kube-state-metrics: Deployments + node exporter: DaemonSet #. Register the Kubernetes cluster as VIM in Tacker. #. Add the VIM info to VimConnectionInfo in VnfInstance table. #. MgmtDriver creates config files for Prometheus. + Metrics Endpoint config: the ENDPOINT of Master/Worker nodes to monitor + Alert rule config: Alert Rule of scaling trigger + Receiver config: the ENDPOINT Tacker Server to receive Alert message #. MgmtDriver sends Metrics Endpoint config file to Prometheus server. + Call reload API of Prometheus server + (Optional) create ConfigMap #. MgmtDriver sends Alert rule and Receiver configs to Alertmanager. + Call reload API of Alertmanager + (Optional) create ConfigMap #. Tacker Server starts to receive Alert messages at PrometheusPlugin. Sample Alert receiving URL: ``POST /alert/vnf_instances/{vnf_instance_id}`` .. note:: The detail of API is described at :ref:`REST API impact`. Sample Metrics Endpoint and Alert rule config in prometheus.yaml: .. code-block:: yaml scrape_configs: - job_name: sample_sd_configs metrics_path: /metrics scheme: http file_sd_configs: - files: - /tacker/*-sd.yaml rule_files: - /tacker/*-rules.yaml .. note:: The config specified by the command-line argument `--config.file` that launches the PrometheusServer. Sample individual Alert rule config: .. code-block:: yaml alert: KubePodCrashLooping expr: rate(kube_pod_container_status_restarts_total{job="kube-state-metrics"}[10m]) * 60 * 5 > 0 for: 15m labels: severity: warning annotations: description: Pod {{ $labels.namespace }}/{{ $labels.pod }} ({{ $labels.container }}) is restarting {{ printf "%.2f" $value }} times / 10 minutes. runbook_url: https://example.com summary: Pod is crash looping. .. note:: This config is the file specified in rule_files of prometheus.yml config. (Optional) Sample individual Alert rule ConfigMap: .. code-block:: yaml kind: ConfigMap apiVersion: v1 metadata: name: tacker-samplevnf-rules data: tacker-samplevnf-rules.yaml: | groups: - name: kubernetes-apps rules: - alert: KubePodCrashLooping annotations: description: Pod {{ $labels.namespace }}/{{ $labels.pod }} ({{ $labels.container }}) is restarting {{ printf "%.2f" $value }} times / 10 minutes. runbook_url: https://example.com summary: Pod is crash looping. expr: | rate(kube_pod_container_status_restarts_total{job="kube-state-metrics"}[10m]) * 60 * 5 > 0 for: 15m labels: severity: warning Sample Receiver config in alertmanager.yaml: .. code-block:: yaml receivers: - name: sample_vnf webhook_configs: - url: http://tacker.example:9890/alert/v1/vnfidexample .. note:: The config specified by the command-line argument `--config.file` that launches the Alertmanager. (Optional) Sample Receiver ConfigMap: .. code-block:: yaml kind: ConfigMap apiVersion: v1 metadata: name: alertmanager-config data: alertmanager.yml: | global: # Files from which custom notification template definitions are read. # The last component may use a wildcard matcher, e.g. 'templates/*.tmpl'. templates: - /prometheus/tacker_template.tmpl # A list of notification receivers. receivers: - name: sample_vnf webhook_configs: - url: http://tacker.example:9890/alert/v1/vnfidexample Sample VNFD ~~~~~~~~~~~ There is no change from spec [#Support_scaling_Kubernetes_Worker-nodes_with_Mgmtdriver]_. Sample request parameters ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ ``InstantiateVnfRequest`` data type in ETSI NFV-SOL003 v2.6.1 [#SOL003]_ for "POST /vnf_instances/{id}/instantiate" requires new attributes in additionalParams. + additionalParams +------------------------------+--------------------------------------------------------------+ | Attribute name | Parameter description | +==============================+==============================================================+ | monitor | Structure. Treats to specify such as monitoring system | | | (``monitorName``) and driver information (``driverInfo``). | +------------------------------+--------------------------------------------------------------+ | function | boolean. | | | True: Enable monitoring feature | | | False: Disable monitoring feature | +------------------------------+--------------------------------------------------------------+ | monitorName | String. In case specifying "prometheus", | | | backend of monitoring feature is to be prometheus. | +------------------------------+--------------------------------------------------------------+ | driverInfo | Structure. Describe the way to control prometheus. | +------------------------------+--------------------------------------------------------------+ | > driverType | String. | | | "external": SCP/SFTP for config file transfer | | | "internal": Kubernetes resources deployed as Prometheus | | | In case of "internal", ``targetInfo`` is not required. | +------------------------------+--------------------------------------------------------------+ | > prometheusScriptsReference | String. Invoked by MgmtDriver when VNF LCM execution. | | | Required Prometheus config is selected with LCM type. | +------------------------------+--------------------------------------------------------------+ | > targetsInfo | list with controlTarget as element. | | | Available only ``driverType`` is "external" | | | Control all the controlTarget configured. | +------------------------------+--------------------------------------------------------------+ + controlTarget: Access information to control external monitoring system +---------------------+----------------------------------------------------------------+ | Attribute name | Parameter description | +=====================+================================================================+ | prometheusHost | String. | | | FQDN or ip address of target PrometheusServer. | +---------------------+----------------------------------------------------------------+ | alertmanagerHost | String. | | | FQDN or ip address of target Alertmanager. | +---------------------+----------------------------------------------------------------+ | authInfo | Structure. | | | Define authentication information to access `host` | +---------------------+----------------------------------------------------------------+ | metricsEndpoint | String. | | ConfigPath | Path of metricsEndpointConfig for target Prometheus. | +---------------------+----------------------------------------------------------------+ | alertRule | String. | | ConfigPath | Path of alertRuleConfig path for target Prometheus. | +---------------------+----------------------------------------------------------------+ | receiver | String. | | ConfigPath | Path of receiverConfig for target Prometheus. | +---------------------+----------------------------------------------------------------+ | prometheus | String. | | reloadApiEndpoint | Endpoint url of reload API of target Prometheus. | +---------------------+----------------------------------------------------------------+ | Alertmanager | String. | | reloadApiEndpoint | Endpoint url of reload API of target Alertmanager. | +---------------------+----------------------------------------------------------------+ Following is a sample of request body: .. code-block:: json { "additionalParams": { "monitor": { "function": true, "monitorName": "prometheus", "monitoringScriptsReference": "./prometheus/prometheus_config.sh", "driverInfo": { "driverType": "external", "targetsInfo": [ { "prometheusHost": "prometheus.example", "alertmanagerHost": "prometheus.example", "authInfo": "", "metricsEndpointConfigPath": "/etc/prometheus/prometheus.yml", "alertRuleConfigPath": "/etc/prometheus/rules/tacker-rule.yml", "receiverConfigPath": "/etc/prometheus/alertmanager.yml", "prometheusReloadApiEndpoint": "http://prometheus.example:9090/-/reload", "alertmanagerReloadApiEndpoint": "http://prometheus.example:9093/-/reload" } ] } } } } (Optional) sample of request body in case of Prometheus in Kubernetes cluster VNF: .. code-block:: json { "additionalParams": { "monitor": { "function": true, "monitorName": "prometheus", "monitoringScriptsReference": "./prometheus/prometheus_config.sh", "driverInfo": { "driverType": "internal" } } } } Sequence for operation ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ .. seqdiag:: seqdiag { node_width = 80; edge_length = 100; "Client" "Tacker-server" "Tacker-conductor" "VnfLcmDriver" "OpenstackDriver" "Heat" "MgmtDriver" "RemoteCommandExecutor" "PrometheusServer" "AlertManager" Client -> "Tacker-server" [label = "1. instantiate VNF"]; Client <-- "Tacker-server" [label = "2. Response 202 Accepted"]; "Tacker-server" -> "Tacker-conductor" [label = "3. trigger asynchronous task"]; "Tacker-conductor" -> "VnfLcmDriver" [label = "4. instantiate VNF"]; "VnfLcmDriver" -> "OpenstackDriver" [label = "5. pre instantiate VNF"]; "VnfLcmDriver" <-- "OpenstackDriver" [label = ""]; "VnfLcmDriver" -> "OpenstackDriver" [label = "6. instantiate VNF"]; "OpenstackDriver" -> "Heat" [label = "7. create stack"]; "OpenstackDriver" <-- "Heat" [label = ""]; "VnfLcmDriver" <-- "OpenstackDriver" [label = "return stack id"]; "VnfLcmDriver" -> "VnfLcmDriver" [label = "8. update DB"]; "VnfLcmDriver" -> "MgmtDriver" [label = "9. instantiate_end"]; "MgmtDriver" -> "Heat" [label = "10. get the new vm info created"]; "MgmtDriver" <-- "Heat" [label = ""]; "MgmtDriver" -> "RemoteCommandExecutor" [label = "11. Changes HAProxy configuration"]; "MgmtDriver" <-- "RemoteCommandExecutor" [label = ""]; "MgmtDriver" -> "RemoteCommandExecutor" [label = "12. Install Kubernetes on the new Master-node"]; "MgmtDriver" <-- "RemoteCommandExecutor" [label = ""]; "MgmtDriver" -> "RemoteCommandExecutor" [label = "13. Install Kubernetes on the new Worker-node"]; "MgmtDriver" <-- "RemoteCommandExecutor" [label = ""]; "MgmtDriver" -> "MgmtDriver" [label = "14. Generate Prometheus Config"]; "MgmtDriver" -> "PrometheusServer" [label = "15. Update Metrics Endpoint config file or ConfigMap"]; "MgmtDriver" <-- "PrometheusServer" [label = ""]; "MgmtDriver" -> "PrometheusServer" [label = "16. Update Alert rule config file or ConfigMap"]; "MgmtDriver" <-- "PrometheusServer" [label = ""]; "MgmtDriver" -> "PrometheusServer" [label = "17. POST PrometheusServer reload API"]; "MgmtDriver" <-- "PrometheusServer" [label = ""]; "MgmtDriver" -> "AlertManager" [label = "18. Update Receiver config file or ConfigMap"]; "MgmtDriver" <-- "AlertManager" [label = ""]; "MgmtDriver" -> "AlertManager" [label = "19. POST PrometheusAlertManager reload API"]; "MgmtDriver" <-- "AlertManager" [label = ""]; "VnfLcmDriver" <-- "MgmtDriver" [label = ""]; "Tacker-conductor" <-- "VnfLcmDriver" [label = ""]; } The procedure consists of the following steps as illustrated in above. Basically the same sequence as described in "VNF-A: Create VMs and set up Kubernetes cluster (Kube-adm)" chapter of spec [#Support_deploying_Kubernetes_cluster_with_MgmtDriver]_, except for the Prometheus Plugin. 1-13. Existing process 14-19. Add following process in ``instantiate_end`` #. Invoke script specified in ``monitoringScriptsReference`` #. (Optional) Deploy Prometheus as Kubernetes resources #. Create Metrics Endpoint config from the Heat response #. Get Alert rule config from VNF Package #. Create Receiver config from ``vnf_instance_id`` #. Send the file, and issue reload API in PrometheusServer - "PUT <PrometheusServer>:<Port>/-/reload" - "POST <PrometheusServer>:<Port>/-/reload" #. Send the files and issue reload API in Alertmanager - "POST <AlertmanagerHost>:<Port>/-/reload" Auto-scale Worker nodes on alert trigger ---------------------------------------- When Prometheus server detect threshold trigger of resource usage or trigger of changing the number of Pods, an alert message is sent to Tacker. Tacker Server receives the alert and invoke Scaling-out/in of Worker nodes. In the Scale operation, MgmtDriver needs to update the config files in Prometheus server because its target nodes are changed. Design of Scale-out operation ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ Following depicts the diagram of auto-scaling out of Worker nodes on the Prometheus alert trigger: :: +------------------------------------------------+ | VNFM | +----------------+ | +----------------+ +-----------------------+ | | | 3. POST | | | | Tacker | | | Alertmanager | alert | | +------------+ | | Conductor | | | +---------------> Prometheus | | | +------------+ | | +--+-------------+ | | | Plugin | | | +-> VmfLcm | | | ^ | | +-+----------+ | | | | Driver +--+ | | | 2. Trigger alert | | | | | | +---------+--+ | | | | | | | 4. Scale | | | | | | | | | | +-v----------+ | | | +---------v--+ | | | +--+-------------+ | | | Vnflcm +-----+ | MgmtDriver | | | | | | | | | Controller | | | ++-+---------+ | | | | Prometheus | | | +------------+ | | | | | | | | Server | | | | | | | +----------v-+ | | | +<------------------------------------+ | | OpenStack | | | +--+-------------+ | | | | | | Infra | | | ^ 6. Update | | | | | | Driver | | | | monitoring | | Tacker Server | | | +------------+ | | | targets | | | | | | | | | | +----------------+ +-----------------------+ | | | | | | | 1. Send metrics +------------------------------------------------+ | | | | +----------------------------------------------------------+ | | KubernetesCluster VNF | | | | | +-------+------+ | | | | 5. Create new worker node | | | v | | | +-------------+ +-------------+ +-------------+ | | | | +--------+ | | +--------+ | | +--------+ | | +------------------+ | Worker | | | | Worker | | | | Master | | | | | +--------+ | | +--------+ | | +--------+ | | | | VM | | VM | | VM | | | +-------------+ +-------------+ +-------------+ | +----------------------------------------------------------+ +----------------------------------------------------------+ | Hardware Resources | +----------------------------------------------------------+ #. Prometheus server collects metrics form Worker nodes. #. Alertmanager receives alert sent from Prometheus Server. #. Alertmanager sends POST request to Tacker with specified URL. #. Tacker Server receives informed alert and invoke Scale operation with VnflcmController. #. Scale operation is triggered and new Worker nodes are created. Request parameters for operation ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ There are no parameters for this operation. .. note:: The request body is defined in Alertmanager. The properties should not be restricted by Tacker to allow flexible operations in Prometheus Plugin. Sequence for operation ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ Following sequence shows components and flow related to scale in invoking process of Worker nodes. Components and flow related to scale out invoking process of Worker nods is same as spec [#Support_scaling_Kubernetes_Worker-nodes_with_Mgmtdriver]_. .. seqdiag:: seqdiag { node_width = 80; edge_length = 100; "Alertmanager" "Tacker-server" "Tacker-conductor" "Prometheus-Plugin" "VnfLcmDriver" "OpenstackDriver" "Heat" "MgmtDriver" "VnfInstance(Tacker DB)" "RemoteCommandExecutor" "Alertmanager" -> "Prometheus-Plugin" [label = "1. Notify Alert to specified URL"]; "Prometheus-Plugin" -> "VnfInstance(Tacker DB)" [label = "2. Get auto-scale config of the VNF"]; "Prometheus-Plugin" <-- "VnfInstance(Tacker DB)" [label = "auto-scale config"]; "Prometheus-Plugin" -> "Prometheus-Plugin" [label = "3. Check auto-scale config", note = "if monitoring status is False, asynchronous task is end"]; "Prometheus-Plugin" -> "Prometheus-Plugin" [label = "4. Invoke dedicated process for auto-scale"]; "Prometheus-Plugin" -> "Tacker-server" [label = "5. Call scale operation"] "Tacker-server" -> "Tacker-conductor" [label = "6. trigger asynchronous task"]; "Alertmanager" <-- "Tacker-server" [label = ""]; "Tacker-conductor" -> "VnfLcmDriver" [label = "7. Start scale processing"]; "VnfLcmDriver" -> "MgmtDriver" [label = "8. scale_start"]; "MgmtDriver" -> "VnfInstance(Tacker DB)" [label = "9. get the vim connection info"]; "MgmtDriver" <-- "VnfInstance(Tacker DB)" [label = ""]; "MgmtDriver" -> "Heat" [label = "10. get the vm info to be removed by scale in operation"]; "MgmtDriver" <-- "Heat" [label = ""]; "MgmtDriver" -> "RemoteCommandExecutor" [label = "11. pre-processing for leaving from Kubernetes cluster"]; "MgmtDriver" <-- "RemoteCommandExecutor" [label = ""]; "VnfLcmDriver" <-- "MgmtDriver" [label = ""]; "Tacker-conductor" <-- "VnfLcmDriver" [label = ""]; "Tacker-conductor" -> "VnfLcmDriver" [label = "12. execute VnfLcmDriver"]; "VnfLcmDriver" -> "OpenstackDriver" [label = "13. execute OpenstackDriver"]; "OpenstackDriver" -> "Heat" [label = "14. resource signal"]; "OpenstackDriver" -> "Heat" [label = "15. update stack"]; "OpenstackDriver" <-- "Heat" [label = ""]; "VnfLcmDriver" <-- "OpenstackDriver" [label = ""]; "Tacker-conductor" <-- "VnfLcmDriver" [label = ""]; } #. Alertmanager receives alert sent from Prometheus Server and inform the alert to specified URL(Tacker Server). .. note:: Alert management of Prometheus format is defined in Prometheus Server. #. Prometheus Plugin get the auto-scale config of the VNF from Tacker DB. #. Prometheus Plugin checks the auto-scale config and exit the process if it is disabled. .. note:: ``VnfInstance.configurableProperties`` has ``isAutoscaleEnabled`` field for auto-scaling process. If set to true, auto-scaling is enabled, otherwise disabled. #. Prometheus Plugin invoke dedicated process for auto-scale. #. Invoke specific process defined in this Prometheus Plugin action. #. Convert received alert with Prometheus format to Scale operation. #. From this step, it is completely the same with the default Scale operation. Sample of alert contents with Prometheus format is below: .. code-block:: json { "receiver": "example", "status": "firing", "alerts": [ { "status": "firing", "labels": { "sample_key": "sample_value" }, "annotations": { "sample_key": "sample_value" }, "startsAt": "0000-00-00T00:00:00.000000000Z", "endsAt": "0000-00-00T00:00:00.000000000Z", "generatorURL": "" } ], "groupLabels": {}, "commonLabels": { "alertname": "example", "instance": "example_instance", "job": "example_job", "severity": "example" }, "commonAnnotations": { "description": "description of alert", "summary": "summary content" }, "externalURL": "", "version": "", "groupKey": "{}:{}" } Terminate For Kubernetes cluster -------------------------------- Terminating Kubernetes cluster VNF which includes Prometheus server, it's not required to update the config files in Prometheus server because the server itself is also terminated. On the other hand, when using pre-built Prometheus server, the Kubernetes cluster should be deleted from the target of monitoring. MgmtDriver needs to support updating the following config files in ``terminate_end`` method. #. MgmtDriver updates config files for Prometheus server. - Metrics Endpoint config: delete the ENDPOINT of Master/Worker nodes to monitor. - Alert rule config: delete Alert Rule of scaling trigger. - Receiver config: delete the ENDPOINT Tacker Server to receive Alert message. #. MgmtDriver sends Metrics Endpoint config file to Prometheus server. - Call reload API of Prometheus server. - (Optional) delete ConfigMap. #. MgmtDriver sends Alert rule and Receiver configs to Alertmanager. - Call reload API of Alertmanager. - (Optional) delete ConfigMap. .. note:: Alert receiving server in Tacker is disabled without any additional process because alert server checks the state of VNF instance before calling auto-scaling API. Alternatives ------------ None Data model impact ----------------- None REST API impact --------------- .. note:: TBD. Security impact --------------- None Notifications impact -------------------- None Other end user impact --------------------- None Performance Impact ------------------ None Other deployer impact --------------------- None Developer impact ---------------- None Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: Yoshito Ito <yoshito.itou.dr@hco.ntt.co.jp> Other contributors: Kyosuke Hori <hori-kyosuke@fujitsu.com> Yoshiyuki Katada <katada.yoshiyuk@fujitsu.com> Ayumu Ueha <ueha.ayumu@fujitsu.com> Liang Lu <lu.liang@fujitsu.com> Work Items ---------- * Implement Tacker server to support: * Expose alert receiving server. * Call Scale-out/in operation on alert message. * Provide a sample script to perform the following tasks: * Deploy Prometheus. * Set up Prometheus. * Add/Delete monitor/alert rule files in Prometheus. * Add/Remove new monitoring target of Worker nodes. * Add new unit and functional tests. Dependencies ============ LCM operations for the Kubernetes cluster depend on the following specifications: + Instantiate operation for the Kubernetes cluster Depends on spec "Support deploying Kubernetes cluster with MgmtDriver" [#Support_deploying_Kubernetes_cluster_with_MgmtDriver]_. + Scale operation for the Kubernetes cluster Depends on spec "Support scaling Kubernetes Worker-nodes with Mgmtdriver" [#Support_scaling_Kubernetes_Worker-nodes_with_Mgmtdriver]_. Testing ======= Unit and functional tests will be added to cover cases required in the spec. Documentation Impact ==================== * Complete user guide will be added to explain how to monitor by Prometheus. * Update API documentation on the API additions mentioned in :ref:`REST API impact`. References ========== .. [#SOL003] https://www.etsi.org/deliver/etsi_gs/NFV-SOL/001_099/003/02.06.01_60/gs_nfv-sol003v020601p.pdf .. [#Support_scaling_Kubernetes_Worker-nodes_with_Mgmtdriver] https://specs.openstack.org/openstack/tacker-specs/specs/wallaby/mgmt-driver-for-k8s-scale.html .. [#Support_deploying_Kubernetes_cluster_with_MgmtDriver] https://specs.openstack.org/openstack/tacker-specs/specs/wallaby/mgmt-driver-for-k8s-cluster.html

commit_message:
Restart octavia rsyslog after updating the config

After creating the octavia rsyslog configuration file, the
octavia_rsyslog container must be restarted if it's already running,
otherwise the new configuration is not applied in the container.

This issue is new, the octavia-ansible playbook was moved from step 5 to
post_deploy, which means that the file is now created after the first start
of the container.

Change-Id: Ibb439d47d551adc5af2d87234b732565af1cc90f
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-ansible refs/changes/66/798066/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: - name: check if octavia rsyslog is running become: true become_user: root shell: | systemctl is-active --quiet tripleo_octavia_rsyslog ignore_errors: true register: octavia_rsyslog_service - name: restart octavia rsyslog service become: true become_user: root systemd: name: tripleo_octavia_rsyslog state: restarted when: - octavia_rsyslog_service.rc == 0

commit_message:
Number of heat queues will keep growing forever after heat-engine restarts

Set TTL as a solution for topic queue engine_worker and heat-engine-listener
to avoid them growing all the time after heat-engin restarts.

This is rabbitmq-server part. eg: we can set heat ttl by:

juju config heat ttl=3600000

Closes-Bug: 1925436
Change-Id: I7b826fe965a200da29020a8f2c6148f76d10a2b0
(cherry picked from commit 707fa0e093af3b6ab636b65b018c29049f7a51ff)
Signed-off-by: Zhang Hua <joshua.zhang@canonical.com>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/charm-rabbitmq-server refs/changes/10/798410/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def configure_ttl(vhost, ttlname, ttlreg, ttl): ''' Some topic queues like in heat also need to set TTL, see lp:1925436 Configure TTL for heat topics in the provided vhost, this is a workaround for filling heat queues and for future other queues ''' log('configure_ttl: ttlname={} ttlreg={} ttl={}'.format( ttlname, ttlreg, ttl), INFO) if not all([ttlname, ttlreg, ttl]): return rabbitmqctl('set_policy', '{ttlname}'.format(ttlname=ttlname), '"{ttlreg}"'.format(ttlreg=ttlreg), '{{"expires":{ttl}}}'.format(ttl=ttl), '--priority', '1', '--apply-to', 'queues', '-p', vhost)

Switch inventory to directory

tripleo-ansible-inventory.yaml, switch to use the native AnsibleRunner
inventory directory instead.

commit_message:
overcloud deploy - net ports with baremetal deploy

--network-ports
  Deploy network ports during baremetal node provisioning.

--network-config (implies --network-ports)
  Deploy network ports and apply the network configuration
  by applying the tripleo_network_config role on the nodes.

Conflicts:
  tripleoclient/v1/overcloud_deploy.py

Change-Id: Ib0c57e57fe5771d914ffd2a93c911cb325152f8b
(cherry picked from commit 05b47bc07ed3ecf1768c5d78929e19538ab8ae85)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-tripleoclient refs/changes/32/797232/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

(Implies "--network-ports")'), default=False, action="store_true")
